Award.AwardTitle: Measuring the effects of dust attenuation on the luminosities and morphologies of disk galaxies
Award.AbstractNarration:
Precisely how galaxies initially form and how they change throughout their lifetimes are among the least understood problems in astrophysics. Such understanding is necessary to uncover how our Universe evolved and to gain insight into the origin of our own Milky Way Galaxy. Many projects are centered on unraveling these mysteries and depend on interpreting observations. This project focuses on how dust in galaxies affects observations. Dust profoundly affects essentially all of the observable diagnostics of galaxies, such as their brightnesses and colors, structures (disks, bulges), color gradients and stellar mass estimates. Previous work demonstrated that more luminous disk galaxies tend to suffer more dust attenuation than low-luminosity galaxies and that their central parts suffer more dust absorption than their outer parts. Yet, two critical questions remain unanswered: (1) How does global dust attenuation---and attenuation gradients---depend simultaneously on the entire set of relevant parameters (luminosity or stellar mass, star formation rate, density or scale length, and structure)? (2) How in detail are commonly-used measures of galaxy structure affected by dust attenuation as a function of galaxy parameters? This project will study these questions by assembling samples of intrinsically similar galaxies (stellar mass, star formation rate, density, structure).

In addition, the principle investigator will lead a collaborative effort to widen the use and assess the impact of effective student-centered pedagogy in University of Michigan introductory undergraduate astronomy classes (e.g., inquiry-based activities, lecture tutorials, think-pair share, diagnostic assessments and learning analytics). This project also involves training of a graduate student, including mentorship and teaching skills; the development of undergraduate research skills in the context of this research project; and involvement in outreach, including in a local elementary school.

More technically, because the samples of similar galaxies are viewed from random angles and edge-on galaxies are much more strongly affected by dust attenuation, studying how the optical properties vary with inclination enables a model-independent measurement of relative dust attenuation as a function of galaxy parameters. However, this crucially depends on the ability to assemble samples of truly similar galaxies, and many previous works use at least some selection criteria that are biased by dust attenuation. This results in samples where the high and low inclination members are not truly similar, and this inclination-dependent cross-sample contamination significantly affects conclusions about the dependence of dust attenuation on galaxy parameters. A critical advance of the investigators' work is that they are developing a set of selection criteria that enables the assembly of samples of similar galaxies in a manner that is unaffected by inclination bias. This advance enables the comparison of the observed properties of samples of truly similar galaxies with unprecedented accuracy. Therefore, the goals of this project are two-fold: (1) To use wide-area near-infrared surveys and this novel inclination-independent measures of galaxy structure to select samples of truly intrinsically similar galaxies in a way that is independent of inclination to a degree never before achieved. (2) To use these samples to measure the dependence of dust attenuation on all relevant galaxy parameters in a complete, unbiased, robust and detailed manner to measure for the first time the effects of dust attenuation on SDSS-based measures of galaxy structure and to measure for the first time the radial gradients in dust attenuation as a function of galaxy properties. The investigators will release their catalogues of structural metrics and other measurements to the public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In order to understand galaxies and what physical processes shape them, astronomers quantify their properties (such as their mass, size, the rate of formation of new stars [called star formation rate] and shape). One challenge that has faced astronomers over the years is that dust -- not dissimilar in its effects and properties to a combination of cigarette smoke and very fine sand -- is present in many galaxies and absorbs and scatters light from these galaxies. As can be seen in a beautiful red dusty sunset, shorter wavelength light -- like the light that we see in the optical wavelength range -- is particularly affected by dust, and accordingly many of the measures that we use to understand properties are biased by dust. 

One important measure of the effects of dust are the differences that one sees between face-on and edge-on versions of very similar galaxies. Many galaxies have disks of stars, dust, and gas; when viewed edge-on one views this disk through much more dust than the face-on configuration, and this difference in properties can be measured and attributed to dust. This method relies on being able to identify galaxies that one thinks are very similar in both face-on and edge-on samples. Yet, because dust's effects are so severe, it has been very difficult to determine which edge-on galaxies correspond to which face-on galaxies, undermining the promise of this powerful and important measure of dust.

It is clear that it would be very useful to identify or construct measures of galaxy properties that are insensitive to viewing angle and dust. Such an effort is now possible, owing to the advent of large near-infrared datasets that are relatively insensitive to dust. Yet, existing measures of galaxy structure are sensitive to viewing angle, undermining the power of these large near-infrared datasets.
The intellectual merit of this proposal was to develop measures of galaxy properties that are insensitive to viewing angle and dust and thereby measure the effects of dust on galaxies. We have developed a novel method to measure galaxy structure (size and shape) that are remarkably insensitive to viewing angle. We have carefully tested and tuned this method and made a catalog of our viewing-angle and dust insensitive measurements of galaxy structure (size and shape) available to the public.

Using these datasets and techniques, we have learned that the effects of dust on galaxies are severe for galaxies like the Milky Way -- we find that when inclining to edge-on, r-band luminosities dim by more than a factor of 2.5, sizes decrease by a factor of 2, ?dust-corrected? estimates of star formation rate drop threefold, our measures of degree of chemical enrichment ('emission line metallicity') decrease by 30%, and edge-on galaxies are half as likely to be classified as star forming.

We have been able to learn how some of these effects depend on galaxy properties. We found that galaxies with more star formation (and therefore, one would infer more gas and dust) are more dimmed and reddened. More massive galaxies tend towards having more reddening and dimming, but the structure of galaxies is very important; compact galaxies are dramatically redder in their face-on configuration, and galaxies with bigger bulges show less difference between their face-on and edge-on views. We use simple models of how light can be affected by dust in galaxies to develop intuition about how dust impacts our measurements. The variation in face-on color of galaxies with structure reflects the overall impact of dust on a galaxy's light reasonably directly. The difference between face-on and edge-on is rather more complex and depends on the relative arrangement of stars and dust. Our measurements, therefore, suggest a simple, physically-motivated scaling of dust impact with gas content, the heavy element content per unit gas mass, and inversely with size squared (as the gas and dust are more concentrated and produce larger effects). 
These new methods, our new catalog and our new measurements of how dust affects measures of galaxy properties will contribute to a careful re-assessment of many published catalogs and inferences about galaxies. Our methods can be applied to existing and upcoming sky surveys, giving public catalogs of galaxy structure that are unbiased by viewing angle and dust (if applied to long wavelength data), permitting a much more robust and accurate census of galaxy properties. 

In terms of broader impacts, our main goal was to widen the circle of instructors using evidence-based and student-centered pedagogy at the University of Michigan and assess the impact of these efforts, largely using pre- and post-surveys of student learning using concept inventories. In parallel, we engaged in activities to develop the careers, skills, and motivation of early-career scientists: one postdoctoral scholar, three graduate students, and 19 undergraduate students.
